info.headline: Flood Advisory issued March 24 at 7:30AM EDT until March 25 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to Mud Creek near Hendersonville. * WHERE...Central Henderson County, North Carolina * WHEN...Until 100 PM EDT Thursday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding along Mud Creek near Hendersonville. Nuisance flooding is defined as less than 2` inundation of farmland, nurseries, woodlands. parks, greenways, boat-access area, and low-water crossings and less than 1` inundation of secondary roads. * On Mud Creek, between 6 and 8 feet: Farmland and other low-lying areas up and downstream from Erkwood Dr are flooding. Backwater effects along Wash Creek may be causing floodwaters to approach the access road to the shopping plaza just south of Gateway Park at the intersection of S Church St and S Main St. E Caswell St may be flooded from storm culvert backwater effects underneath the railroad tracks adjacent to Mud Creek. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 657 AM EDT, No additional rainfall is expected for about another week. However, periods of moderate to heavy rain on Wednesday resulted in 2-4 inches of storm-total rainfall across Henderson County, with localized totals exceeding 5 inches within the headwaters of Mud Creek. This caused excessive runoff and significant stream rises across much of Henderson County, but especially within the Mud Creek watershed. Small streams have fully receded across Henderson County, but high flows continue along Mud Creek this morning. Mud Creek crested at 9.74 feet at 12:45am and is now falling steadily. Mud Creek is currently at 8.12 feet and will continue to fall towards the Action/Advisory Stage of 6.5 feet by this afternoon. The Flood Advisory for nuisance flooding will remain in effect until the stream falls below Action/Advisory Stage. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hendersonville, Flat Rock, Mountain Home, Laurel Park, Valley Hill and Crab Creek.
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed.
